subject: PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPANESE AND SOUTH KOREAN STOCK NEWS: Australia mid-cap earnings, Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (7203 JT) will buy London-based asset manager TT International

Alumina (AWC AT) - Co. H1 adj. net AUD 219.5mln vs. Prev. AUD 305.8mln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Co. also announces Carmel Mulhern has been appointed Executive Group General Counsel and Governance. (Newswires)

JAPAN

SOUTH KOREA

Trade - South Korea agreed to a free trade deal with the UK as they look to maintain their ties post-Brexit. (Yonhap)

Other News

DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China MOFCOM said China will have to retaliate if US persists on current course and that any new measures will lead to escalation but declined to comment on possible retaliatory measures and stated it will publish its unreliable entity list soon. Furthermore, MOFCOM added the impact from US tariffs is manageable and that China is fully confident it can handle all challengers, while it also stated that trade teams from both sides have been keeping in touch. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said US tried to suppress China, but the damage caused is less than what China had feared. (Twitter)

South Korea announced they will not be renewing their intelligence accord with Japan, while Japan's Foreign Minister Kono later commented it is extremely regrettable that South Korea has decided to end their intelligence agreement. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK PM Johnson reiterated the UK must leave the EU on October 31st deal or no deal but added we can achieve a deal and can find a way forward. PM Johnson also stated that whatever happens regarding Brexit, France and the UK want to deepen ties, while he added under no circumstances will UK institute checks or controls at Irish border, that there is adequate time to find a solution and where there is a will, there is a way. (Newswires)

French President Macron said the backstop was "indispensable" to preserving political stability and single market integrity. Macron also stated that we cannot changed the Withdrawal Agreement although the coming month may be useful and that we need viability in the next 30-days on the Irish Backstop, while he suggested no-one will be waiting until October 31st for a good solution. Furthermore, an official in Macron's office said talks between the French President and UK PM were constructive in which they agreed to continue exchanges until end of September to try and reach an agreement on Brexit. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said a solution to the backstop which keeps the Good Friday Agreement and insures integrity of EU market can be found by 31st October, while she clarified her recent comments in which she denied setting a 30-day deadline to come up with a solution to the backstop and instead said “you want to do in three or two years, you can do in 30 days”. There were also comments from a senior German official that Chancellor Merkel was being polite in reference to her 30-day remark and those who know Merkel say she concludes "the train has already left the station" and it is almost impossible to stop a no deal Brexit. (Newswires/AFP)

ECB Minutes stated the slowdown is more protracted than previously thought and downside risks are more pervasive which could necessitate projection cut. Furthermore, members widely shared the view that the recent declines in longer-term inflation expectations were a matter of concern and that incoming data had been broadly in line with the June projections although a mechanical update of the short-term HICP outlook suggested a somewhat lower path. Members also broadly supported the proposal made by Chief Economist Lane to task the relevant Eurosystem Committees with examining options for future policy measures, although some concerns were raised regarding possible unintended consequences of a tiered system and its ability to fully mitigate the potential effects of negative policy rates on bank intermediation. (Newswires)

German Bundesbank spokesperson said sees no need for fiscal stimulus at the moment. In other news, there were reports that EU officials want to set up a EUR 100bln wealth fund to bolster "European champions" against American and Chinese business rivals like Google, Apple and Alibaba. (Newswires/Politico)

Italian President Mattarella said new elections is a choice that cannot be taken lightly and that some parties he has spoken to said they are working towards a deal to create a coalition but needed more time which he will give. Mattarella also stated new consultations will be held on Tuesday and Italian PD Leader Zingaretti has given Mattarella their 5 preconditions for a government, while Deputy PM Salvini said following a meeting with President Mattarella, we want elections but are still willing to re-form a government with 5-Star if it is more constructive. (Newswires)

  • EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 47.0 vs. Exp. 46.2 (Prev. 46.5). (Newswires)
  • EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 53.4 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 53.2)
  • EU Markit Composite Flash PMI (Aug) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.5)
  • German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 43.6 vs. Exp. 43.0 (Prev. 43.2)
  • German Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.5)
  • German Markit Composite Flash PMI (Aug) 51.4 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.9)

 

GEOPOLITICS

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif said he is prepared to work on France's proposals regarding a nuclear deal. (Newswires)

 

US

US President Trump criticized the Fed again as he suggested said the Fed does not allow what needs to be done and puts US at a disadvantage in which he noted a strong dollar and no inflation, while Trump also questioned why the US has to pay higher interest rates than Germany and other countries and urged the Fed to let US win big, rather than just win. (Twitter)

White House will reportedly not move forward with plan to cut foreign aid by billions according to sources, although US Secretary of State Pompeo later stated that President Trump is still undecided on what to do. (Newswires)

Fed's George (Voter, Hawk, Dissenter) said it is not time for accommodation and the labour market remains strong, while she added the rate cut in July was not needed and it is not time to provide accommodation in the US without signs the outlook is getting weaker. George also stated we are at rate equilibrium and would be happy to leave rates where they are now, while she suggested the economy absorbed the downside risk, is poised to expand and that monetary policy decisions take into account longer-term not just the short-term fluctuations in the stock market. (Newswires)

Fed’s Harker (Non-voter, Neutral) said Fed makes decisions based on US economy and is pretty much where it needs to be as he does not see a case for further stimulus. Harker added that he is on hold right now, that he did not agree with the July rate cut and will not endorse a rate cut in September, while he added we are roughly at neutral and that he is not sympathetic to the insurance cut argument. (Newswires)

  • US Markit Manufacturing PMI (Aug P) 49.9 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.4), New orders Index 49.5 (Prev. 51.7), both at lowest in 10 years. (Newswires)
  • US Markit Services PMI (Aug P) 50.9 vs. Exp. 52.8 (Prev. 53.0)
  • US Markit Comp PMI (Aug P) 50.9 (Prev. 52.6)
  • US Leading Index Change (Jul) M/M 0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.3%)

 

MARKET RECAP

There was not a lot to be too cheerful about in US trade, and this is reflected in the downbeat tone risks assets trade with in the first half of Thursday. Following slightly hawkish Fed minutes on Wednesday, another wave of hawkish Fed commentary out of Jackson Hole kept risk assets on the defensive in early US trade. Additionally, PMI data saw the manufacturing segment fall into contraction, adding to the gloom. However, equities were supported in afternoon trade, with some suggesting that China purchases of US soybeans was a bullish sign, and attributed the news for helping stocks rise off lows and claw back earlier losses. Attention now falls onto the address of Fed Chair Powell at Jackson Hole (1500 BST/1000 EDT on Friday). Boeing (BA) traded higher after both Moody’s and Cowen cheered the return of the MAX jet by Q4. BA was also boosted after sourced reports that it has plans to increase production of 737 jets to 52/month in February 2020, if regulators approve the 737 MAX jet to fly in Q4. Nordstrom (JWN) was flirting with its largest percentage increase in over a decade following a strong profit beat; EPS 0.90 (Exp. 0.76), the stock was up over 15% despite missing on revenue. L Brands (LB), however were hit on earnings, with revenues falling short of expectations; it also reported SSS decline of 1%. Keysight (KEYS) and Synopsis (SNPS) were also higher after earnings beats. Tesla (TSLA) was in focus after reports in Manager Magazin that it is preparing for a takeover offer from Volkswagen (VOW3), though VW denied the claim. Meanwhile, Politico reported that EU officials want to set up a EUR 100bln wealth fund to bolster "European champions" against American and Chinese business rivals like Google (GOOG), Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT), Baidu (BIDU), Alibaba (BABA) and Tencent (TCEHY). In M&A, State AG’s are reportedly trying to block the T-Mobile (TMUS) & Sprint (S) doing a deep dive into Dish’s (DISH) financials and ability to compete as a fourth major wireless network. S&P 500 0% at 2928, NASDAQ-100 -0.3% at 7723, Dow Jones 0.2% at 26300.     

Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement, although +/- 1bps or so vs Wednesday’s settlement levels. There was a steepening bias in early trade, however, underpinned by the ‘hawkish’ FOMC meeting minutes. A little bit of indecision has been seen in Thursday trade, with traders questioning if Powell will be able to deliver on the market’s dovish expectations. In pre-market US trade, Treasuries moves in sympathy with Bunds. However, the focus was back on Fed officials after remarks from Fed’s hawkish voter (dissenter) George, as well as somewhat hawkish comments from the Fed’s Harker; the net impact of these was for risk assets to come under pressure. Focus now on Powell, with risks of a disappointment.  US T-note futures (U9) settled 7+ ticks lower at 130-09+.

US Market Wrap - 22nd August 2019: Hawkish Fedspeak ahead of Powell at Jackson Hole on Friday
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, Dollar flat/down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Hawkish Fedspeak ahead of Powell; ECB minutes signal concern; positive rhetoric, but no Brexit breakthrough; weak US PMIs, slightly better EZ PMIs; China still buying US soybeans; No breakthrough on Italy, Mattarella to update next week.
  • COMING UP: Powell at Jackson Hole, Japanese National CPI, Canadian Retail Sales, US New Home Sales.

* MARKET WRAP: There was not a lot to be too cheerful about in US trade, and this is reflected in the downbeat tone risks assets trade with in the first half of Thursday. Following slightly hawkish Fed minutes on Wednesday, another wave of hawkish Fed commentary out of Jackson Hole kept risk assets on the defensive in early US trade. Additionally, PMI data saw the manufacturing segment fall into contraction, adding to the gloom. However, equities were supported in afternoon trade, with some suggesting that China purchases of US soybeans was a bullish sign, and attributed the news for helping stocks rise off lows and claw back earlier losses. Attention now falls onto the address of Fed Chair Powell at Jackson Hole (1500 BST/1000 EDT on Friday).

* FED: Following a slightly hawkish FOMC meeting minutes on Wednesday, Jackson Hole commentary from Fed officials has started off on a hawkish note. Fed’s George (voter, hawk, dissenter) said it was not the time for further accommodation. George said that the rate cut in July was not needed, and she was not open to providing more accommodation without signs the outlook is getting weaker. She believes rates are at an equilibrium, and would be happy to leave rates where they are now. George noted that the economy has absorbed the downside risks, and is poised to expand. Fed’s Harker (non-voter, neutral) said that based on the state of the US economy, the Fed is where it needs to be, and he does not see a case for further stimulus. Harker stated that he did not agree with the July rate cut, but went along with it to get rates back to neutral, but indicated that he would not endorse a rate cut in September. He argued, however, that if tariffs hit consumers, then it would be a cause for concern, which may lead to changing his view. Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) said he was in favour of the rate cut in July, but is taking time to assess all factors heading into the September FOMC, adding that he would like to avoid taking further action on rates, noting they can impact savers and encourage more risk-taking. On the economy, he sees growth around 2.0% this year, but with downside risks.

* US/CHINA: China purchased a small number of US soybeans between 9-15th August, following on from declarations to stop purchases of US farm products, sources said. However, the shipment was very small. China imported just under 10k tonnes between 9-15th August for delivery in the current marketing year, Reuters reported, and 66k tonnes (around one cargo) for the next year. China's MOFCOM 5th August said that Chinese companies had stopped buying US ags, and the purchases reported today were a little surprising. Elsewhere, Chinese MOFCOM said it will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation; it declined to comment on possible retaliatory measures, but said it would publish an unreliable entity list soon. It also added that the impact from US tariffs were manageable, and China is fully confident it can handle all challengers. Finally, MOFCOM noted that China/US trade teams have been keeping in touch.

* US LEADING INDEX: at 0.5% M/M against an estimate for 0.3%. July's increase follows back-to-back modest declines, with housing permits, unemployment insurance claims, stock prices driving the improvement. However, the Conference Board said that the manufacturing sector continues show signs of weakness, and the yield spread was negative for a second consecutive month. "While the LEI suggests the US economy will continue to expand in the second half of 2019, it is likely to do so at a moderate pace," the Conference Board added.  

* US PMIs: Often ignored by US players, but moved the market today after the manufacturing component fell into contraction. August’s survey data provides a clear signal that economic growth has continued to soften in the third quarter, Markit said, the PMIs for manufacturing and services remain much weaker than at the beginning of 2019 and collectively point to annualized GDP growth of around 1.5%. "The most concerning aspect of the latest data is a slowdown in new business growth to its weakest in a decade, driven by a sharp loss of momentum across the service sector," Markit said, "survey respondents commented on a headwind from subdued corporate spending as softer growth expectations at home and internationally encouraged tighter budget setting. The survey compiler also noted that manufacturing companies continued to feel the impact of slowing global economic conditions, with new export sales falling at the fastest pace since August 2009. "Business expectations for the year ahead became gloomier in August and remain the lowest since comparable data were first available in 2012. The continued slide in corporate growth projections suggests that firms may exert greater caution in relation to spending, investment and staff hiring during the coming months." Analysts warn about reading too much into the data, however, since the Markit PMI for the US has mostly given an unreliable read of ISM in the last year.

* EUROZONE PMIs: Prelim August PMI moved slightly higher, against expectations of a small fall, though remains in its 51-52 range, which Pantheon Macroeconomics says is consistent with GDP growth of around 1.0%. There was an improvement in the manufacturing PMI, though it still remains in contractionary territory for the seventh straight month, which will likely add pressure on the ECB; services ticked up slightly. Pantheon thinks that the song remains the same, however: manufacturing is still suffering, but services—effectively the domestic economy—is still relatively robust, the consultancy says, noting that new orders and output growth in manufacturing remain soft, primarily due to weakness in Germany, which dragged employment in this sector down for the fourth month running. By contrast, Pantheon notes that the services sector is more robust. Meanwhile, the German composite and manufacturing ticked up, while the services saw a trivial fall. New orders are still edging lower, while work backlogs fell at the quickest pace since 2012.

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson’s meeting with French President Macron failed to yield any breakthrough (hardly a surprise), with both reiterating arguments that we have heard in recent days. Despite that, rhetoric was constructive. Germany Chancellor Merkel once again gave an sanguine set of comments on Brexit; however, Germany had to clarify her remarks (that a backstop alternative was possible within 30 days), adding that she was not setting the UK a deadline, but she said “that what one can achieve in three or two years can also be achieved in 30 days.”

* EUROZONE CONSUMER SENTIMENT: August Eurozone consumer confidence fell to -7.1 from July’s -6.6 reading, a slight miss on the expected -7.0, and largely consistent with recent lacklustre household spending data. Capital Economics said that August’s reading is historically consistent with household spending growth of between 1.5% and 2.0%. However, it caveats that since 2017, the measure has overstated household spending growth, and add that other factors such as the collapse of Italy’s government, the increasing risk of a no-deal Brexit and signs of a slowing labour market; as such the consultancy expects household spending growth is running at a more conservative 1.5% Y/Y. 

* ITALY: Italian President Mattarella says new elections is a choice that cannot be taken lightly; some parties he has spoken to said they are working towards a deal to create a coalition, but needed more time. Mattarella says new consultations will be held on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the PD party is willing to enter a coalition government with the 5SM. The PD’s willingness to reach an agreement with 5SM increases the chances that the two parties can form a coalition, which would avert the need for early elections. With that said, analysts note that the PD’s demand could still prove to be a source of friction since they are likely incompatible with the 5SM position. The PD’s offer seems to be premised on five conditions, including loyal membership of the EU, giving Parliament a central role, and a reversal of Lega’s anti-immigration policies. One of the sticking points for a coalition would then be who would become prime minister, the BBC reported, since neither PD leader Zingaretti nor 5SM leader Di-Maio have shown any interest in the job, leaving questions on who would lead the coalition. If the two parties fail to reach deal, autumn elections appear likely, which raises the possibility that the Lega will storm the vote, winning a majority – a scenario analysts have said could put pressure on Italian assets.

* ECB MINUTES: The July meeting minutes echoed concerns expressed by ECB President Draghi during his post-meeting press conference; policymakers view the slowdown as more protracted than previously thought, with downside risks more pervasive. Moreover, from an inflation perspective, declines in both actual and longer-term inflation expectations are framed as “a matter of concern.” As such, members “broadly supported the proposal made by Chief Economist Lane to task the relevant Eurosystem Committees with examining options for future policy measures”. In terms of the scope and sequencing of potential further measures, the accounts noted “experience had shown that a policy package – such as the combination of rate cuts and asset purchases – was more effective than a sequence of selective actions”, a viewpoint largely in-fitting with recent comments from Finland’s ECB member Rehn, who called for an “impactful and significant” easing package. However, as suggested by Draghi himself last month, concerns were raised regarding possible unintended consequences of tiered rates and its ability to mitigate the potential negative impact of negative rates on banks, implying that a tiered deposit rate system is not necessarily a given accompaniment to rate cuts and asset purchases. It is worth noting that the meeting took place before the Fed July rate cut, thus any prior concerns held by policymakers have likely been heightened with members likely more unanimous now in their desire to present a comprehensive easing package next month. ING looks for “a 20bp rate cut of the deposit rate, a small tiering system, a repricing of the TLTROs and a restart of QE with some 30 billion euro per month” at the September meeting.

* S.KOREA/JAPAN: South Korea announced it would not be renewing its intelligence accord with Japan; in recent rhetoric, South Korea has been threatening to pull out of the pact, but Japan had maintained the view that it wanted to keep it intact. Japan's Foreign Minister Kono said later that it is extremely regrettable that South Korea has decided to end their intelligence agreement. The breakdown of the pact is a blow to the US, which has benefitted from the intelligence operation to gauge North Korea’s missile activity; North Korea on Thursday carried out live fire drills by bombing replicas of South Korea's F-15K fighter jets, surface to air missiles, and a radar.

* IRAN: Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif said he is prepared to work on France's proposals regarding a nuclear deal; earlier Zarif reiterated that Iran will not start a war in the Persian Gulf but "will defend ourselves”. Zarif’s comments follow French President Macron’s on Wednesday, that he would hold talks with Iranian officials ahead of the G7 in attempts to salvage the 2015 Nuclear Deal.

* TREASURIES: US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 7+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-09+. Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement, although +/- 1bps or so vs Wednesday’s settlement levels. There was a steepening bias in early trade, however, underpinned by the ‘hawkish’ FOMC meeting minutes. A little bit of indecision has been seen in Thursday trade, with traders questioning if Powell will be able to deliver on the market’s dovish expectations. In pre-market US trade, Treasuries moves in sympathy with Bunds. However, the focus was back on Fed officials after remarks from Fed’s hawkish voter (dissenter) George, as well as somewhat hawkish comments from the Fed’s Harker; the net impact of these was for risk assets to come under pressure. Focus now on Powell, with risks of a disappointment.

* WTI FUTURES (V9) SETTLE USD 0.33 LOWER AT USD 55.35/BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 0.38 LOWER AT USD 59.92: Price action in the crude complex was again a function of risk sentiment, following supply-side factors (a net US inventory build) yesterday. The complex, seemingly mirroring moves in US equity futures, falling on disappointing Markit PMI data, which coincided with a broader risk off move. Brent fell briefly below the USD 60.00 handle before paring losses, whilst WTI found a floor around USD 55.00. Reports that Russian crude oil production has averaged 11.327mln bpd over the first three weeks of August may also have been weighing, given the country’s 11.191mln bpd OPEC+ production target. However, some desks argued that this increase might be temporary, not an indication of weakening Russian compliance, as the country looks to make up for a fall in production due to pipeline contamination issues during May through July. Taking more of a bird’s eye view of the complex, since the escalation in trade tension between the US/China at the end of May, WTI seems to be caught in the middle of a 50-61 range, with global growth-related concerns keeping a lid on prices at the upper bound, whilst risks to supply (Iran and Venezuela) provide a floor. Given veiled threats from Iranian President Rouhani yesterday (that if Iran’s oil exports are brought down to zero, international waterways will not have the same security as before) shows little sign of abating anytime soon. 

* FX WRAP: USD: After trading firmer overnight and in European trade, the buck is slightly negative heading into APAC trade, after soft PMI data raised concerns about the health of US manufacturing, despite the data correlating poorly with the more-watched ISM. Yesterday’s FOMC meeting minutes revealed that the ‘mid-cycle adjustment’ phrase used by Powell was not an off-the-cuff remark, and as the Fed wants to give the impression it is not on a pre-set course. Powell’s remarks at Jackson Hole on Friday are key (minutes were backwards looking, Powell is expected to provide some colour on future moves), although the markets seeming desire for a dovish outcome risks disappointing expectations. Nevertheless, those dovish expectations were cited by newswires as a reason for the buck’s weakness. There will be attention in whether Powell still fames the FOMC’s July cut as a mid-cycle adjustment (ie. a one-off), or whether he will allude to further loosening of rates; given that some FOMC participants have suggested that July’s insurance cut might have borrowed from similar insurance cuts in the 1990s, desks will be watching to what extent the Fed can frame three consecutive 25bps rate cuts as ‘insurance’, as it did in 1995 and 1998. Any disappointment out of Powell’s comments that leads to US appreciation will likely weigh on EMFX like MXN, INR, ZAR and BRL, analysts said. CNY: The buck’s strength has lifted USDCNY to fresh cyclical highs just shy of 7.10. Analysts said it was a sign that the gradual, controlled weakness of the yuan is being allowed to continue; however, IFR’s analysts noted that while USDCNY has hit fresh highs, the trade weighted CNY has not. EUR: Was trading in its familiar, thin range just beneath the 1.11 mark ahead of PMI data, which came in slightly better than anticipated, though doesn’t change the dial much; it didn’t change the EUR’s dial all that much today, either. JPY:  USDJPY gains pared overnight, in wake of the FOMC minutes, after Japan’s economy minister said there were still gaps that needed addressing in a US/Japan trade deal. GBP: Commentary from French officials (Paris now has a default assumption of a no deal Brexit, sources say) has given Sterling traders a reason to be defensive ahead of the weekend’s G7 confab. AUD: Weak PMIs, which fell sub-50 are keeping the Aussie defensive, and the implied probability of an RBA October rate cut rose to 52%. subject: US Market Wrap - 22nd August 2019: Hawkish Fedspeak ahead of Powell at Jackson Hole on Friday
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, Dollar flat/down, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Hawkish Fedspeak ahead of Powell; ECB minutes signal concern; positive rhetoric, but no Brexit breakthrough; weak US PMIs, slightly better EZ PMIs; China still buying US soybeans; No breakthrough on Italy, Mattarella to update next week.
  • COMING UP: Powell at Jackson Hole, Japanese National CPI, Canadian Retail Sales, US New Home Sales.

* MARKET WRAP: There was not a lot to be too cheerful about in US trade, and this is reflected in the downbeat tone risks assets trade with in the first half of Thursday. Following slightly hawkish Fed minutes on Wednesday, another wave of hawkish Fed commentary out of Jackson Hole kept risk assets on the defensive in early US trade. Additionally, PMI data saw the manufacturing segment fall into contraction, adding to the gloom. However, equities were supported in afternoon trade, with some suggesting that China purchases of US soybeans was a bullish sign, and attributed the news for helping stocks rise off lows and claw back earlier losses. Attention now falls onto the address of Fed Chair Powell at Jackson Hole (1500 BST/1000 EDT on Friday).

* FED: Following a slightly hawkish FOMC meeting minutes on Wednesday, Jackson Hole commentary from Fed officials has started off on a hawkish note. Fed’s George (voter, hawk, dissenter) said it was not the time for further accommodation. George said that the rate cut in July was not needed, and she was not open to providing more accommodation without signs the outlook is getting weaker. She believes rates are at an equilibrium, and would be happy to leave rates where they are now. George noted that the economy has absorbed the downside risks, and is poised to expand. Fed’s Harker (non-voter, neutral) said that based on the state of the US economy, the Fed is where it needs to be, and he does not see a case for further stimulus. Harker stated that he did not agree with the July rate cut, but went along with it to get rates back to neutral, but indicated that he would not endorse a rate cut in September. He argued, however, that if tariffs hit consumers, then it would be a cause for concern, which may lead to changing his view. Fed's Kaplan (non-voter, neutral) said he was in favour of the rate cut in July, but is taking time to assess all factors heading into the September FOMC, adding that he would like to avoid taking further action on rates, noting they can impact savers and encourage more risk-taking. On the economy, he sees growth around 2.0% this year, but with downside risks.

* US/CHINA: China purchased a small number of US soybeans between 9-15th August, following on from declarations to stop purchases of US farm products, sources said. However, the shipment was very small. China imported just under 10k tonnes between 9-15th August for delivery in the current marketing year, Reuters reported, and 66k tonnes (around one cargo) for the next year. China's MOFCOM 5th August said that Chinese companies had stopped buying US ags, and the purchases reported today were a little surprising. Elsewhere, Chinese MOFCOM said it will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation; it declined to comment on possible retaliatory measures, but said it would publish an unreliable entity list soon. It also added that the impact from US tariffs were manageable, and China is fully confident it can handle all challengers. Finally, MOFCOM noted that China/US trade teams have been keeping in touch.

* US LEADING INDEX: at 0.5% M/M against an estimate for 0.3%. July's increase follows back-to-back modest declines, with housing permits, unemployment insurance claims, stock prices driving the improvement. However, the Conference Board said that the manufacturing sector continues show signs of weakness, and the yield spread was negative for a second consecutive month. "While the LEI suggests the US economy will continue to expand in the second half of 2019, it is likely to do so at a moderate pace," the Conference Board added.  

* US PMIs: Often ignored by US players, but moved the market today after the manufacturing component fell into contraction. August’s survey data provides a clear signal that economic growth has continued to soften in the third quarter, Markit said, the PMIs for manufacturing and services remain much weaker than at the beginning of 2019 and collectively point to annualized GDP growth of around 1.5%. "The most concerning aspect of the latest data is a slowdown in new business growth to its weakest in a decade, driven by a sharp loss of momentum across the service sector," Markit said, "survey respondents commented on a headwind from subdued corporate spending as softer growth expectations at home and internationally encouraged tighter budget setting. The survey compiler also noted that manufacturing companies continued to feel the impact of slowing global economic conditions, with new export sales falling at the fastest pace since August 2009. "Business expectations for the year ahead became gloomier in August and remain the lowest since comparable data were first available in 2012. The continued slide in corporate growth projections suggests that firms may exert greater caution in relation to spending, investment and staff hiring during the coming months." Analysts warn about reading too much into the data, however, since the Markit PMI for the US has mostly given an unreliable read of ISM in the last year.

* EUROZONE PMIs: Prelim August PMI moved slightly higher, against expectations of a small fall, though remains in its 51-52 range, which Pantheon Macroeconomics says is consistent with GDP growth of around 1.0%. There was an improvement in the manufacturing PMI, though it still remains in contractionary territory for the seventh straight month, which will likely add pressure on the ECB; services ticked up slightly. Pantheon thinks that the song remains the same, however: manufacturing is still suffering, but services—effectively the domestic economy—is still relatively robust, the consultancy says, noting that new orders and output growth in manufacturing remain soft, primarily due to weakness in Germany, which dragged employment in this sector down for the fourth month running. By contrast, Pantheon notes that the services sector is more robust. Meanwhile, the German composite and manufacturing ticked up, while the services saw a trivial fall. New orders are still edging lower, while work backlogs fell at the quickest pace since 2012.

* BREXIT: UK PM Johnson’s meeting with French President Macron failed to yield any breakthrough (hardly a surprise), with both reiterating arguments that we have heard in recent days. Despite that, rhetoric was constructive. Germany Chancellor Merkel once again gave an sanguine set of comments on Brexit; however, Germany had to clarify her remarks (that a backstop alternative was possible within 30 days), adding that she was not setting the UK a deadline, but she said “that what one can achieve in three or two years can also be achieved in 30 days.”

* EUROZONE CONSUMER SENTIMENT: August Eurozone consumer confidence fell to -7.1 from July’s -6.6 reading, a slight miss on the expected -7.0, and largely consistent with recent lacklustre household spending data. Capital Economics said that August’s reading is historically consistent with household spending growth of between 1.5% and 2.0%. However, it caveats that since 2017, the measure has overstated household spending growth, and add that other factors such as the collapse of Italy’s government, the increasing risk of a no-deal Brexit and signs of a slowing labour market; as such the consultancy expects household spending growth is running at a more conservative 1.5% Y/Y. 

* ITALY: Italian President Mattarella says new elections is a choice that cannot be taken lightly; some parties he has spoken to said they are working towards a deal to create a coalition, but needed more time. Mattarella says new consultations will be held on Tuesday. Meanwhile, the PD party is willing to enter a coalition government with the 5SM. The PD’s willingness to reach an agreement with 5SM increases the chances that the two parties can form a coalition, which would avert the need for early elections. With that said, analysts note that the PD’s demand could still prove to be a source of friction since they are likely incompatible with the 5SM position. The PD’s offer seems to be premised on five conditions, including loyal membership of the EU, giving Parliament a central role, and a reversal of Lega’s anti-immigration policies. One of the sticking points for a coalition would then be who would become prime minister, the BBC reported, since neither PD leader Zingaretti nor 5SM leader Di-Maio have shown any interest in the job, leaving questions on who would lead the coalition. If the two parties fail to reach deal, autumn elections appear likely, which raises the possibility that the Lega will storm the vote, winning a majority – a scenario analysts have said could put pressure on Italian assets.

* ECB MINUTES: The July meeting minutes echoed concerns expressed by ECB President Draghi during his post-meeting press conference; policymakers view the slowdown as more protracted than previously thought, with downside risks more pervasive. Moreover, from an inflation perspective, declines in both actual and longer-term inflation expectations are framed as “a matter of concern.” As such, members “broadly supported the proposal made by Chief Economist Lane to task the relevant Eurosystem Committees with examining options for future policy measures”. In terms of the scope and sequencing of potential further measures, the accounts noted “experience had shown that a policy package – such as the combination of rate cuts and asset purchases – was more effective than a sequence of selective actions”, a viewpoint largely in-fitting with recent comments from Finland’s ECB member Rehn, who called for an “impactful and significant” easing package. However, as suggested by Draghi himself last month, concerns were raised regarding possible unintended consequences of tiered rates and its ability to mitigate the potential negative impact of negative rates on banks, implying that a tiered deposit rate system is not necessarily a given accompaniment to rate cuts and asset purchases. It is worth noting that the meeting took place before the Fed July rate cut, thus any prior concerns held by policymakers have likely been heightened with members likely more unanimous now in their desire to present a comprehensive easing package next month. ING looks for “a 20bp rate cut of the deposit rate, a small tiering system, a repricing of the TLTROs and a restart of QE with some 30 billion euro per month” at the September meeting.

* S.KOREA/JAPAN: South Korea announced it would not be renewing its intelligence accord with Japan; in recent rhetoric, South Korea has been threatening to pull out of the pact, but Japan had maintained the view that it wanted to keep it intact. Japan's Foreign Minister Kono said later that it is extremely regrettable that South Korea has decided to end their intelligence agreement. The breakdown of the pact is a blow to the US, which has benefitted from the intelligence operation to gauge North Korea’s missile activity; North Korea on Thursday carried out live fire drills by bombing replicas of South Korea's F-15K fighter jets, surface to air missiles, and a radar.

* IRAN: Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif said he is prepared to work on France's proposals regarding a nuclear deal; earlier Zarif reiterated that Iran will not start a war in the Persian Gulf but "will defend ourselves”. Zarif’s comments follow French President Macron’s on Wednesday, that he would hold talks with Iranian officials ahead of the G7 in attempts to salvage the 2015 Nuclear Deal.

* TREASURIES: US T-NOTE FUTURES (U9) SETTLE 7+ TICKS LOWER AT 130-09+. Major curve spreads were mixed at settlement, although +/- 1bps or so vs Wednesday’s settlement levels. There was a steepening bias in early trade, however, underpinned by the ‘hawkish’ FOMC meeting minutes. A little bit of indecision has been seen in Thursday trade, with traders questioning if Powell will be able to deliver on the market’s dovish expectations. In pre-market US trade, Treasuries moves in sympathy with Bunds. However, the focus was back on Fed officials after remarks from Fed’s hawkish voter (dissenter) George, as well as somewhat hawkish comments from the Fed’s Harker; the net impact of these was for risk assets to come under pressure. Focus now on Powell, with risks of a disappointment.

* WTI FUTURES (V9) SETTLE USD 0.33 LOWER AT USD 55.35/BBL; BRENT (V9) SETTLES USD 0.38 LOWER AT USD 59.92: Price action in the crude complex was again a function of risk sentiment, following supply-side factors (a net US inventory build) yesterday. The complex, seemingly mirroring moves in US equity futures, falling on disappointing Markit PMI data, which coincided with a broader risk off move. Brent fell briefly below the USD 60.00 handle before paring losses, whilst WTI found a floor around USD 55.00. Reports that Russian crude oil production has averaged 11.327mln bpd over the first three weeks of August may also have been weighing, given the country’s 11.191mln bpd OPEC+ production target. However, some desks argued that this increase might be temporary, not an indication of weakening Russian compliance, as the country looks to make up for a fall in production due to pipeline contamination issues during May through July. Taking more of a bird’s eye view of the complex, since the escalation in trade tension between the US/China at the end of May, WTI seems to be caught in the middle of a 50-61 range, with global growth-related concerns keeping a lid on prices at the upper bound, whilst risks to supply (Iran and Venezuela) provide a floor. Given veiled threats from Iranian President Rouhani yesterday (that if Iran’s oil exports are brought down to zero, international waterways will not have the same security as before) shows little sign of abating anytime soon. 

* FX WRAP: USD: After trading firmer overnight and in European trade, the buck is slightly negative heading into APAC trade, after soft PMI data raised concerns about the health of US manufacturing, despite the data correlating poorly with the more-watched ISM. Yesterday’s FOMC meeting minutes revealed that the ‘mid-cycle adjustment’ phrase used by Powell was not an off-the-cuff remark, and as the Fed wants to give the impression it is not on a pre-set course. Powell’s remarks at Jackson Hole on Friday are key (minutes were backwards looking, Powell is expected to provide some colour on future moves), although the markets seeming desire for a dovish outcome risks disappointing expectations. Nevertheless, those dovish expectations were cited by newswires as a reason for the buck’s weakness. There will be attention in whether Powell still fames the FOMC’s July cut as a mid-cycle adjustment (ie. a one-off), or whether he will allude to further loosening of rates; given that some FOMC participants have suggested that July’s insurance cut might have borrowed from similar insurance cuts in the 1990s, desks will be watching to what extent the Fed can frame three consecutive 25bps rate cuts as ‘insurance’, as it did in 1995 and 1998. Any disappointment out of Powell’s comments that leads to US appreciation will likely weigh on EMFX like MXN, INR, ZAR and BRL, analysts said. CNY: The buck’s strength has lifted USDCNY to fresh cyclical highs just shy of 7.10. Analysts said it was a sign that the gradual, controlled weakness of the yuan is being allowed to continue; however, IFR’s analysts noted that while USDCNY has hit fresh highs, the trade weighted CNY has not. EUR: Was trading in its familiar, thin range just beneath the 1.11 mark ahead of PMI data, which came in slightly better than anticipated, though doesn’t change the dial much; it didn’t change the EUR’s dial all that much today, either. JPY:  USDJPY gains pared overnight, in wake of the FOMC minutes, after Japan’s economy minister said there were still gaps that needed addressing in a US/Japan trade deal. GBP: Commentary from French officials (Paris now has a default assumption of a no deal Brexit, sources say) has given Sterling traders a reason to be defensive ahead of the weekend’s G7 confab. AUD: Weak PMIs, which fell sub-50 are keeping the Aussie defensive, and the implied probability of an RBA October rate cut rose to 52%. Meanwhile, EMFX was under pressure, with FOMC slight hawkishness being cited by traders.

Nordstrom (JWN) was flirting with its largest percentage increase in over a decade following a strong profit beat; EPS 0.90 (Exp. 0.76), the stock was up over 15% despite missing on revenue. subject: Daily FX Wrap: Sterling soars as Merkel maintains backstop resolution momentum
content:
GBP

The Pound was breathing a sigh of relief as UK PM Johnson and French President Macron concluded their meeting in Paris with a relatively amicable press conference and a pledge to work together over the coming month in an effort to bridge the Irish backstop gap. However, Cable scaled 1.2200 from a low close to 1.2100 and extended through the previous mtd high (1.2210) all the way up to circa 1.2265 at best after German Chancellor Merkel suggested that a solution to the border impasse that complies with the Good Friday Agreement and keeps the integrity of the EU single market can be found. Her latest comments seem even more constructive (at face value) than Tuesday’s remarks that also boosted Sterling before some qualification (in that any ‘practical solution’ will not come via a renegotiated WA, but the PD). Indeed, Eur/Gbp (that has been a better barometer of Brexit sentiment) reversed through chart support ahead of 0.9100 and under 0.9050 vs 0.9155+ at one stage, as the single currency faltered after a post-Eurozone PMI spike.

USD

The Dollar retreated further from recent highs in wake of a sub-50 US Markit manufacturing PMI, as new orders slumped from 51.7 to 49.5 and also hit decade lows. However, the DXY managed to hold above 98.000 (just) and gleaned support from relatively hawkish Fed commentary (via George and Harker) before the official start of the Jackson Hole Symposium, alongside broader safe-haven positioning that favoured the Greenback over other currencies apart from the Yen (and Gold of course).

EUR 

As noted above, the Euro was boosted by preliminary Eurozone PMIs that were better than expected in headline terms, but not so good at sub-component level. Hence, Eur/Usd struggled to sustain gains beyond 1.1100 again and retested circa 1.1065 lows for a 3rd time before ‘stabilising’.

NZD/AUD 

The Kiwi and Aussie have been lagging all day and extended losses from recent recovery peaks above 0.6400 and 0.6800 respectively as risk sentiment soured again, with Nzd/Usd down to 0.6360 and Aud/Usd almost touching 0.6750 after downbeat CBA PMIs overnight.

CAD

The Lonnie is still tethered to 1.3300 vs its US counterpart with little to choose from early NA data given that Canadian wholesale trade and US initial claims both beat consensus, while the aforementioned disappointing Markit survey was partially offset by a downturn in crude prices.

EM

No confirmation, but price action/behaviour since Usd/Cnh got to within a whisker of 7.1000 could easily be attributed to official or Chinese bank inspired defence of a tolerance level after MOFCOM comments stressing that any further US tariffs will be countered. Elsewhere, declines against the Buck on general risk aversion was an overall theme, but the Try was also hit by increasingly bearish technical impulses on its way down to 5.7900 and hardly derived any comfort from an upturn in Turkish consumer confidence as a result. Conversely, the Idr was relatively resilient after another unexpected, albeit not shock 25 bp BI rate cut as the accompanying statement inferred that might be the final one and done, or at least enough form the time being.

subject: Fixed and FX latest: bonds depressed and spreads wider, Buck flat to firmer
content: Better than expected US weekly claims and Canadian wholesale trade data will probably be overshadowed by the upcoming preliminary Markit PMIs and KC survey that is timely given the JH event in the state, but the overall and prevailing bear-steepening trend in debt market remains intact. Bunds have pared some losses after testing another downside chart support level alongside Gilts and US Treasuries, at 177.65, 133.84 and 130-04 respectively, but have pared some losses, while the Dollar remains mixed vs major peers and flattish against the Loonie around the 1.3300 axis.

subject: Germany Chancellor Merkel says a solution to the backstop which keep the Good Friday Agreement and insures integrity of EU market can be found by 31st October
reaction_details: In a reaction further constructive comments from Merkel, Cable popped higher from 1.2160 as high as 1.2240, before the move pared to 1.2210. Cable, at the time of writing, holding above the 1.2200 handle. Technicians now eye the 31st of July high at 1.2250 as the next possible area of resistance. In terms of EURGBP; the cross fell briefly below 0.9060 from 0.9105, with resistance jut below at 0.9051 (the mid-July low).

subject: Fed's George (Hawk, Voter, Dissenter) says negative rates are not appropriate at this time, reiterates earlier comments that she does not see any signal of a downturn in the economy as the moment
content: • Says she still thinks the Fed's balance sheet is large, may have helped cause the yield curve inversion
analysis_details: George's comments on the balance sheet are interesting, particularly since minutes for the July meeting this week revealed that participants were concerned by the persistent inversion of the 3m/10-yera part of the curve; here, George appears to be dismissing that concerns, attributing the inversion to the size of the Fed's balance sheet, which grew to around USD 4.5trln during the crisis (this argument on why the inversion is less significant this cycle has been thrown around by analysts and some Fed participants in the past)

subject: ECB Minutes state slowdown is more protracted than previously thought and downside risks are more pervasive, could necessitate projection cut
content:
• Members also broadly supported the proposal made by Chief Economist Lane to task the relevant Eurosystem Committees with examining options for future policy measures

  • Regarding longer-term inflation expectations, members widely shared the view that the recent declines were a matter of concern
  • The incoming data had been broadly in line with the June projections, although a mechanical update of the short-term HICP outlook suggested a somewhat lower path.

  • Markets will be looking at the account of the July meeting for any clues of what to expect in September
  • However, the perspective from the minutes might be considered to be slightly stale given the shift in global rate expectations since the previous meeting

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 22nd August 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Core European bourses are marginally softer this morning as sentiment took a downturn in-spite of strong EZ data
  • Chinese Commerce Ministry said China will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation, unreliable entity list will be published soon
  • Italian President Mattarella is meeting with parties today, announcement on a potential PD/5-Star deal expected after 16:00BST today
  • USD is mixed, with safe haven JPY remaining firm and antipodeans weighed on as CNH flirted with the 7.10 mark vs. USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Flash PMIs, US Initial Jobless Claims and EZ Consumer Confidence (Flash), Jackson Hole Symposium Begins, ECB Minutes & French President Macron meeting UK PM Johnson
  • Earnings from: Salesforce.com, HP

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the early momentum from Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by strong retailer earnings and after the FOMC minutes did little to alter the landscape as they showed a divide among officials on rate cuts. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (U/C) were both higher at the open with tech and energy the outperformers on the busiest day of the earnings season in Australia, while Tokyo trade was less decisive as price action eventually reflected a choppy currency and after a lack of progress in talks between Japanese and South Korean Foreign Ministers to resolve the ongoing spat. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were subdued amid CNY weakness and as Hong Kong’s property sector suffered the brunt of the Hong Kong protests with developers said to be reducing prices to support sales, although losses in the mainland have been cushioned by the PBoC’s liquidity efforts. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially unchanged amid similar uneventful trade in T-notes, but later saw mild support after firmer demand at the enhanced liquidity auction for long end JGBs and as risk tone began to deteriorate.

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos for a daily net injection of CNY 30bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 7.0490 vs. Exp. 7.0519 (Prev. 7.0433)

Canadian PM Trudeau said he will defend Canada’s interests in China dispute and stated “we do not escalate, we also do not back down”, while he also urged dialogue and respect for fundamental freedoms in Hong Kong. (Newswires)

Chinese Commerce Ministry said China will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation, declines to comment on possible retaliatory measures, will publish unreliable entity list soon. (Newswires)

- Impact from US tariffs manageable, China is fully confident it can handle all challngers

- China/US trade teams have been keeping in touch

 

GEOPOLITICS

North Korea has carried out live fire drills by bombing replicas of South Korea's F-15K fighter jets, surface to air missiles and a radar. (Newswires)

South Korea state they will not be renewing their intelligence accord with Japan, according to the Blue House. (Newswires)

Iran has displayed a new locally built mobile missile defence system, reported via Iranian news agencies. (Newswires)

Iranian Foreign Minister Zarif says he is prepared to work on France's proposals regarding a nuclear deal. (Newswires)

Senior EU Official says the EU would be against bringing Russia back to the current format of G7 world leaders & summit could temper some trade tensions, there is blueprint for positive developments in EU-US trade ties. (Newswires)

UK/EU

Italian President Mattarella will meet with the Democratic Party at 1000BST, Forza Italia at 1100BST, Salvini’s League at 1500BST and the 5-Star Movement at 1600BST today in order to decide the next steps for Italian politics. In terms of comments from the President he wants parties to show clear signals of a possible deal on Thursday regarding the forming of a new government and wants to see clear progress next week on this. (Newswires)

Italian PD Leader Zingaretti has told President Mattarella their 5 preconditions for a government, and adds that they will not enter into a government at 'any cost'. (Newswires)

German Finance Ministry said early indicators suggest sustained slowdown in the industrial sector and that external risks have risen significantly which is fuelling business uncertainty, while there were separate reports the German government is reportedly considering a ban on negative interest rates for retail savers. (Newswires/FAZ)

EU Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 47.0 vs. Exp. 46.2 (Prev. 46.5)

- EU Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 53.4 vs. Exp. 53.0 (Prev. 53.2)

- EU Markit Comp Flash PMI (Aug) 51.8 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.5)

French Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 51.0 vs. Exp. 49.5 (Prev. 49.7)

- French Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 53.3 vs. Exp. 52.5 (Prev. 52.6)

- French Markit Comp Flash PMI (Aug) 52.7 vs. Exp. 51.8 (Prev. 51.9)

German Markit Manufacturing Flash PMI (Aug) 43.6 vs. Exp. 43.0 (Prev. 43.2)

- German Markit Services Flash PMI (Aug) 54.4 vs. Exp. 54.0 (Prev. 54.5)

- German Markit Comp Flash PMI (Aug) 51.4 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 50.9)

EQUITIES

European stocks have given up the earlier PMI-induced gains [Eurostoxx 50 -0.1%] as the sentiment seen from firmer EZ metrics across the board failed to persist, and amid little follow-through from FOMC Minutes. Italy’s FTSE MIB (+0.4%) is kept afloat as Italian President Mattarella holds a barrage of talks with party leaders in search of a coalition to fill the country’s political void in order to pass the 2020 budget later this year. Meanwhile, UK’s FTSE 100 (-0.5%) marginally lags its peers as heavyweight tobacco stocks (Imperial Brands -1.0%, British American Tobacco -1.4%) weigh on the index amid news that  the US House Energy and Commerce Committee launched a probe into four e-cigarette companies, British American Tobacco, Atria Group (MO), Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) and Reynolds American; seeking information on Cos’ research into public heath impacts, marketing practices and promotion of e-cigarette use by adolescents. Moreover, broker downgrades for BHP (-1.7%), Anglo American (-2.0%) and Rio Tinto (-0.4%) adds further pressure on the index. Sectors are almost all in the red with cyclical stocks faring worse than defensives, in-fitting with the current risk tone. In terms of individual movers, Thyssenkrupp (+5.4%) shares jumped to the top of the Stoxx 600 amid reports that parties interested in Co's elevator unit include Advent, Apollo, CVC, Carlyle, KKR and possibly EQT, according to Manager Magazin. Meanwhile, BBVA (+1.3%) and Caixabank (+1.7%) benefit from broker upgrades at HSBC.

Amazon (AMZN) is on track to invest over USD 15bln this year in infrastructure, tools, services, people and programs to aid third-party sellers. (Newswires)

FX

EUR - Not the strongest G10 currency, but the Euro perked up in wake of the flash Eurozone PMI surveys that were firmer than forecast across the board. Eur/Usd started to climb after the French preliminary prints and then crossed 1.1100 and beyond when German and pan headlines maintained the recovery trend, but faded again before testing offers reportedly waiting at 1.1120. Note also, hefty option expiries between 1.1095 and the big figure may be exerting a gravitational pull given 1.65 bn rolling off at the NY cut.

GBP/JPY - The other major outperformers as the Dollar continues to drift post-FOMC minutes that failed to provide any further or clearer insight on guidance for the September policy meeting. Indeed, the DXY remains tightly bound just above the 98.000 handle and inside relatively narrow confines for the week so far (between 98.451-115), awaiting Fed chair Powell for clearer pointers (hopefully) at Jackson Hole on Friday. Meanwhile, Sterling is still seemingly taking the positive view that there is time left (albeit limited and decaying) to resolve the Irish backstop stalemate and reach some sort of Brexit deal before October 31, with Cable keeping its head above 1.2100, but capped by the 21 DMA circa 1.2154 and Eur/Gbp pivoting 0.9150 even though the single currency is underpinned as noted above. Elsewhere, the safe-haven Yen retains an underlying bid around 106.50 amidst ongoing global trade and geopolitical tensions after tough talks between the US and Japan failed to produce a breakthrough and SK not renewing its intelligence sharing agreement with Japan.

NZD/AUD/CAD - All on the backfoot vs their US counterpart as the Kiwi loses more ground after failing to sustain recovery momentum above 0.6400 and the Aussie likewise following fleeting bounces over 0.6800, but also undermined by CBA PMIs overnight showing sub-50 manufacturing and composite readings. The Loonie is holding up a bit better after Wednesday’s frothy Canadian CPI, but unable to rally too far beyond 1.3300 ahead of wholesale trade data later today.

SEK/NOK - Also weaker, partly on fundamentals and technically as Swedish unemployed jumped in SA terms and Norway trimmed its Q3 oil investment estimate, with Eur/Sek back up above 10.7000 and Eur/Nok hovering nearer the top of 9.9550-9145 trading parameters against the backdrop of faltering risk appetite.

EM - Widespread losses against the Greenback, but Cnh and Try depreciation looks particularly eye-catching as the offshore Yuan teeters around 7.1000 amidst more warnings from China that retaliation is in the pipeline if the US presses ahead with extra tariffs on September 1st. Meanwhile, the Lira continues to list and tested 100 DMA support circa 5.7922 even though Turkish consumer sentiment picked up in August.

South Africa Treasury has instructed government departments to draft budget reductions of 5% for 2020, then 6% and 7% for the respective years after. (Newswires)

FX Option Expiries of Note:

- EUR/USD 1.1040-50 (1.7BLN), 1.1055-60 (800M), 1.1095-00 (1.65BLN), 1.1135-40 (960M), 1.1165-70 (1.6BLN), 1.1175-80 (1.3BLN)

- USD/JPY 105.00-10 (1.55BLN), 106 (576M), 106.65 (325M), 107.00-04 (1.1BLN)

FIXED

Not much traction for Gilts via a dire CBI retail survey with the headline sales balance tumbling and other components also bleak, but the 10 year UK benchmark is holding off Wednesday’s Liffe low (just) within a 134.29-71 range, like Bunds that briefly inched below yesterday’s Eurex intraday base before paring some losses between 178.18-94 parameters. Meanwhile, Italian bonds are consolidating and awaiting more news from Rome with the 10 year BTP back under 143.00 having just topped the round number earlier. Turning to US Treasuries, futures have retreated and the curve has reverted to steepening ahead of claims data and the Markit prelim PMIs that could bounce in lime with the Eurozone surveys.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are modestly firmer on the day with the former around the 56/bbl mark, whilst the latter remains near the 60.50/bbl level having found a base at 60/bbl. News flow has been light thus far for the complex with price action likely to be dictated by macro developments/sentiment heading into Fed Chair Powell’s speech tomorrow. Meanwhile, the WTI/Brent Arb widened to around USD 4.60/bbl vs. USD 3.60 earlier in the week. ING notes that “it does appear that the relative strength in WTI is starting to raise concerns over how it may impact demand for US oil from overseas buyers”. Elsewhere, gold is marginally softer and pivots on either side of 1500/oz ahead of ECB Minutes and as the Jackson Hole Symposium goes on underway, with Fed Chair Powell due to speak tomorrow. Copper prices declined further below the 2.6/lb mark as risk appetite somewhat waned.

DNB Markets lowers its 2019 Brent forecast to USD 66/bbl (Prev. USD 73/bbl), 2020 to USD 64/bbl (Prev. USD 75/bbl) and 2021 to USD 68/bbl (Prev. USD 76/bbl). (Newswires)

subject: Nomura Quants: Ahead of Fed’s Jackson Hole Nomura highlight their view on 3 key questions
content:
1. Is it safe to conclude that the risk of a second bottom in global equity has been avoided?
  2. Have hedge funds stopped selling off US equity?
  3. Is there no chance of another share price correction triggered by another inversion of the UST 2yr-10yr curve?

1)

  • Nomura note that although the risk of this has declined, it has not been completely eliminated.
  • Noting that 50-100bp worth of cuts from the Fed (actual or signalled) and coordinated fiscal response by global governments have stemmed the risk somewhat. However, these factors largely stem from a downturn in sentiment and the rally in equity is somewhat wishful thinking until more clarity emerges from Powell on Friday.
  • The recovery in equity sentiment is also still within average ranges since 2009, following the trend pattern sentiment may see a downturn from 26th August onwards.

2)

  • A varied approach: macro hedge funds continue to buy on dips. However, CTAs and other trend-watchers are remaining largely on the side-lines, but may feel it necessary to begin unwinding long positions if the VIX increases.
  • CTAs continue to scope the market by closing longs when the S&P 500 is underneath 2960, only 60% of long positions held since the 16th July peak have been unwound.
  • Nomura reiterate that 2920-60 is the area to sell the rally in SPX futures.

3)

  • Nomura highlight that yesterday’s inversion in 2/10 did not cause a significant overreaction in equity markets, as this inversion was predominantly down to 2yr price moves due to FOMC minutes optimism.
  • It remains possible that long-term investors could move to a more conservative stance in the event of another inversion, noting that long-term investors would perhaps begin moving their investment weighting to bonds from stocks if global growth concerns continue

Chinese Commerce Ministry said China will have to retaliate if US persists on current course, adding that any new measures will lead to escalation, declines to comment on possible retaliatory measures, will publish unreliable entity list soon
content:
• Impact from US tariffs manageable, China is fully confident it can handle all challngers
  • China/US trade teams have been keeping in touch
analysis_details:
• This comes ahead of the 10% US levy on part of USD 300bln worth of Chinese goods effective September 1st

POSSIBLE CHINA RETALIATION:

  • Tariff Increase: China has currently taxed USD 110bln worth of US goods at a range of 20-25%. This levy could increase further to match the effect of US’ tax imposition on the outstanding goods, albeit the size of the goods US affected is likely to remain as US imports far more goods from China than vice versa.
  • An unreliable entity list: This list could exclude some US firms from doing business with Chinese companies.
  • Rare-earth restrictions: Another “weapon” in China’s arsenal. Prohibiting these rare earth exports to the US will significantly affect the hi-tech/electronic producers which may be forced to slow or even halt some US production. SCMP reported earlier this month that China’s rare earth producers are ready to weaponise their supply control and pass any tariffs as costs to US customers.
  • Yuan: The Chinese currency weakened last week to above 7.00 against the USD, for the first time in a decade, after the US' latest escalation of trade wars. The move higher resulted in a significant risk-off reaction in markets. The PBOC's response was somewhat predictable (China will not participate in competitive devaluation of the Yuan, although the currency move prompted the US to label China as a 'currency manipulator' by the US). Despite this, the daily USD/CNY fixing has been creeping higher (ex-last two days), whilst PBoC officials kept reiterating that the Yuan is at an appropriate level at present.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

22nd August 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mixed as the region failed to sustain the early momentum from Wall St where sentiment was underpinned by strong retailer earnings and after the FOMC minutes did little to alter the landscape as they showed a divide among officials on rate cuts. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (-0.1%) were both higher at the open with tech and energy the outperformers on the busiest day of the earnings season in Australia, helped by improved results from Origin Energy and Santos, while Tokyo trade was less decisive as price action eventually reflected a choppy currency and after a lack of progress in talks between Japanese and South Korean Foreign Ministers to resolve the ongoing spat. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) were subdued amid CNY weakness and as Hong Kong’s property sector suffered the brunt of the Hong Kong protests with developers said to be reducing prices to support sales, although losses in the mainland have been cushioned by the PBoC’s liquidity efforts.

FTSE 100

HSBC (HSBA LN)/Aviva (AV/ LN) - HSBC is reportedly mulling a bid for some of the Asian operations being sold by Aviva which could be valued between USD 3-4bln. (Newswires) HSBC shares fell 0.6% in Hong Kong trade.

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. has rejected UK pilot union BALPA’s offer of framework for talks. Union said planned strike of UK pilots employed by Co. will go ahead today and a further 72-hour strike is planned for 2nd September. Co. does not expect significant disruptions from the Aug 22-24 strikes. (Guardian) Note: Co. had earlier been granted an injunction to stop a separate 48-hour strike by Irish pilots. 

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – US House Energy and Commerce Committee has launched a probe into four e-cigarette companies, seeking information on Cos’ research into public heath impacts, marketing practices and promotion of e-cigarette use by adolescents. Cos involved include British American Tobacco, Atria Group (MO), Japan Tobacco (2914 JT) and Reynolds American. (Newswires)

Tesco (TSCO LN) – Co. will have the option to ban products which use too much non-recyclable packaging from next year. (Guardian)

National Grid (NG/ LN) – Co. are reportedly close to announcing a deal with General Electric (GE) for the measurement of ‘inertia’ in the energy system, which acts as a supply buffer. In an attempt to stabilise the energy system to prevent blackouts. (Guardian)

EX-DIVS: Berkeley Group (BKG LN), Carnival (CCL LN), Croda International (CRDA LN), Imperial Brands (IMB LN), London Stock Exchange (LSE LN), Prudential (PRU LN), Reckitt Benckiser (RB/ LN) and Schroders Plc (SDR LN) will trade without entitlement to its latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 5.7 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

William Hill (WMH LN) – Co. is poised to launch its sportsbook at the Tropicana Evansville Casino next month and is pending approval by the state’s gaming commission, in time for the approaching NFL season. (Times)

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) – Division heads at the Co. now have to ask approval from the Co’s CEO Sewing, CFO von Moltke and Deputy CEO von Rohr to fill open positions at the Co.; only role requests which are deemed as ‘critical’ should be submitted. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

Initially to be tested with Boeing (BA), but Qantas are reportedly yet to have decided on whether Boeing of Airbus will be the craft supplier for the flights when they become commercial. (Newswires)
